I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Power Generation Efficiency Improvement Project. The report 
also  describes  the  proposed  administration  of  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  be  provided  by  the 
Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  for  the  Power  Sector  Reform  and  Sustainability  Support 
Program, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to 
me by the Board, approve the administration of the TA.  
 
2. 
The project will (i) help Uzbekistan address the widening electricity demand–supply gap 
by installing additional 900 megawatt (MW) generation capacity in a least-cost and most efficient 
manner  through  combined  cycle  gas  turbine  units  (CCGT)  at  the  existing  Talimarjan  thermal 
power plant (TPP); and (ii) complement and deepen ongoing sector reforms, strengthen financial 
management  practices,  and  improve  the  corporate  governance  of  Uzbekenergo,  the  largest 
power utility of Uzbekistan. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
Over the past decade, the Uzbekistan economy grew robustly at an average rate of 8%, 
3. 
lifting a significant number of people out of poverty.1 The energy sector underpins Uzbekistan’s 
sustained growth, contributing to 10% of its gross domestic product and a quarter of its exports. 
However, Uzbekistan is also one of the most energy-intensive economies in the world. Its aging 
and dilapidated Soviet era energy and industrial infrastructure is a major factor for the prevailing 
poor  energy  efficiency.  Lack  of  adequate  investments  in  new  power  plants  is  inhibiting  the 
retirement  of  old  and  inefficient  power  plants  (para.  4).  Uzbekistan  has  adopted  an  ambitious 
program to pursue an industrialized, upper middle-income country status by 2030 (Vision 2030).2 
Energy sector modernization and reforms are the centerpiece of this vision.   
 
4. 
Uzbekistan is rich in hydrocarbon resources with large proven reserves of about 1.8 trillion 
cubic meter of natural gas, 600 million barrels of oil, and 3 billion tons of coal. The primary energy 
consumption of Uzbekistan is dominated by natural gas, which provides 82% of its energy mix.3 
Uzbekistan is the eighth largest producer of natural gas in the world. In 2016, it produced more 
than 62 billion cubic meters of natural gas, of which 20% was exported.4 Natural gas is also the 
dominating fuel in the country’s electricity generation mix, contributing 85% of the total electricity 
produced in 2016 (59 terawatt-hours [TWh]).5 The installed generation capacity in the country is 
13.4 gigawatts, of which more than 11 gigawatts is fueled by natural gas TPPs. However, more 
than 40% of this capacity is in 40–50 years old plants, which are in poor condition and require 
urgent replacement and/or major rehabilitation.

 The weighted average thermal efficiency of its gas-based thermal power generation 
5. 
fleet  is  33%,  and  some  plants  have  efficiencies  as  low  as  23%,6 compared  with  modern 
CCGTs  with  thermal  efficiencies  of  53%–60%. 7  Uzbekistan  has  more  than  230,000 
kilometers  of  transmission  and  distribution  lines  with  an  average  age  of  30  years. 
Transmission and distribution losses are high at more than 20%.   
 
6. 
 Aging infrastructure and insufficient investments have increasingly resulted in unreliable 
power supply in recent years. The World Bank estimates the electricity supply–demand gap at 
2,085 gigawatt-hours in 2016, and to reach 14,624 gigawatt-hours by 2020 if required investments 
are not made. Blackouts are still occasional for  4–6 hours a day during winter when electricity 
demand is highest in both rural areas and big cities. Hardest hit are the socially vulnerable people 
in  the  southern  and  western  regions  of  Uzbekistan.  Schools  and  hospitals  are  unable  to  fully 
operate in late autumn and winter because of the lack of reliable electricity, putting education and 
health care systems at risk. Power shortages are often considered high risk for doing business in 
a country where investor interest is eroding.  
 
Uzbekistan is strategically located for power trade with neighboring countries and is the 
7. 
largest  power  exporter  to  Afghanistan,  supplying  35%  of  its  electricity  demand in 2015.8 In the 
interconnected and coordinated power system of the Soviet era, Uzbekistan was expected to use 
its fossil fuel generation to make up for autumn and winter power shortages in hydropower-rich 
countries  such  as  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  Tajikistan.  Improving  efficient  power  generation 
capacity in Uzbekistan can increase power trade with neighboring countries, improving electricity 
supply security across Central Asia.   
 
In coordination with development partners, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been 
8. 
supporting Uzbekistan’s energy sector through a two-pronged strategy of (i) investing in critical 
energy infrastructure to modernize and upgrade the system and (ii) leveraging incremental sector 
reforms and governance improvement.9 In April 2010, ADB approved the first energy project in 
Uzbekistan,  which  included  the  installation  of  900  MW  CCGT  units  at  the  Talimarjan  TPP  in 
southern Uzbekistan.10 In August 2017, CCGT units designed to generate 6.5 TWh of electricity 
annually were successfully put into operation, alleviating some of the existing electricity shortages 
(para. 5).11 The reform elements under the Talimarjan Power Project included the introduction of 
financial reporting following International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) at Uzbekenergo 
(footnote 10), a vertically integrated stated-owned enterprises (SOE) for thermal power generation 
including Talimarjan TPP, transmission and distribution. This helped Uzbekenergo generate its 
first IFRS consolidated financial statements for FY2015 and adopt external audits based on the 
International  Standards  on  Auditing  starting  FY2011,  contributing  to  improved  accountability, 
transparency, and good governance.12

2 

 

 

 The  government  is  committed  to  reforms  and  liberalization.  In  September  2017,  it 
9. 
announced  the  bold  and  much-needed  policy  action  to  unify  its  foreign  exchange  regime  and 
allow the sum (Uzbekistan currency) to float against foreign currencies. While this policy action is 
expected  to  reap  important  medium-  to  long-term  economic  benefits,  it  has  caused  a  sharp 
depreciation of the local currency by about 90% against the US dollar in the short term. 13  This 
has led to a deterioration of Uzbekenergo’s debt–equity ratio because of the utility’s exposure to 
foreign currency debts. In response, Uzbekenergo proactively launched a time-bound financial 
recovery  action  plan  prioritizing  the  following  measures:  (i)  revenue  increase  through 
development and implementation of tariff methodology, (ii) corporate restructuring and divestment 
of noncore assets, and (iii) improvement of operating efficiency and IFRS-compliant classification 
and impairment provisions on account receivables and payables.14  
 
The  project  will  install  an  additional  900  MW  CCGT  capacity  at  the  Talimarjan  TPP  to 
10. 
directly address the issues discussed in paras. 4–6 and help the government initiative to retire 
3.4 gigawatts of old generation capacity. It will also support the government’s sector reforms and 
Uzbekenergo’s financial recovery action plan through (i) developing a power sector master plan 
to  rationalize  long-term  investments;  (ii)  preparing  a  tariff  reform  road  map  to  increase 
Uzbekenergo’s revenue to the level of full cost recovery including pass-through of costs arising 
from external factors such as foreign exchange rate risks, and fuel prices; (iii) introducing IFRS to 
a key power generation subsidiary of Uzbekenergo, which will be replicated in other subsidiaries 
and  pave  the  way  for  corporatization  of  generation  companies;  and  (iv)  supporting  the 
development of a detailed implementation plan for Uzbekenergo’s financial recovery action plan. 
These reform actions will complement the budget support program requested by the government 
to cushion the impact of foreign exchange reform.  
 
11. 
The project is aligned with the government’s strategic emphasis on the energy efficiency 
enhancement and reliable power supply to support its vision for an upper middle-income country 
by  2030  (footnote  2).  It  is  included  in  the  country  operations  business  plan,  2017–2019  for 
Uzbekistan  as a  priority project  and  is also well  aligned with the  Country  Partnership Strategy 
(2012–2016) for Uzbekistan’s priority to support for energy efficiency to generate power surpluses 
to expand energy export to Afghanistan and other energy-deficient countries in the region. The 
project also directly supports the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program (CAREC) 
energy  strategy,  which  prioritizes  energy  security,  and  reliable  and  more  affordable  energy 
services in the region through balanced  development  of  region’s  energy  sources and stronger 
integration  of  energy  markets. 15 The  project  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  energy  policy  supporting 
improved  energy  security  and  reduced  emissions  of  greenhouse  gases  through  the  energy 
efficiency  improvement,  which  will  contribute  Uzbekistan’s  nationally  determined  contributions 
under the Paris Agreement of reducing carbon intensity by 10% by 2030 from its 2010 level.  
 
B. 
 
12. 
(footnote 2). The outcome will be efficiency and reliability of power supply improved.16  

The project impact will be reliable energy supply increased and energy intensity reduced

Outputs 

C. 
 
13. 
Output 1: Talimarjan thermal power plant capacity increased. Output 1 will expand 
Talimarjan TPP capacity by an additional 900 MW through the installation of two 450 MW CCGT 
units in combined heat and power mode.17 The combined heat and power feature will supplement 
the heat supply to nearby Nuriston town to meet its growing heat demand for household and rural 
small businesses, obviating the need for additional heat-only boilers. The addition will increase 
the aggregate capacity of Talimarjan TPP to 2,600 MW and improve its average thermal efficiency 
from 48% to 52%.18  
 
14. 
Output 2: Uzbekenergo financial operation and performance improved. Output 2 will 
address challenges constraining Uzbekenergo’s capacity to generate adequate cash for capital 
investments.  Attached  TA  (para.  20)  will  directly  contribute  to  output  2  by  undertaking  critical 
analytical work to prepare a sound basis for the next generation of reforms. In particular, the TA 
will undertake (a) the development of a power sector master plan; (b) tariff reform roadmap (para. 
10);  and  (c)  associated  capacity  building  to  support  and  deepen  sector  reforms,  strengthen 
financial management practices, and improve corporate governance of Uzbekenergo. TA outputs 
will be firmed up after extensive stakeholder consultations. 
 
15. 
Output 3: Institutional capacity enhanced. Output 3 will strengthen the capacity for the 
operation and maintenance of the plant, and provide technical support for the timely and adequate 
maintenance  of  gas  turbines.  Under  the  project,  an  operational  plan  for  the  community  social 
center will be developed and implemented to strengthen ongoing gender mainstreaming activities.

III. 

 ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

20. 
The attached transaction TA will address challenges constraining the sustainability of the 
sector through (i) the power sector master plan to rationalize the long-term investment; (ii) the 
tariff  structure  and  regulatory  framework  reform  road  map;  and  (iii)  capacity  enhancement  of 
Uzbekenergo  staff  for  power  sector  development  planning.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost 
$2.1 million, of which $2.0 million will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction  and  administered  by  ADB.  Uzbekenergo  is  the  executing  agency  and  will  provide 
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  office  accommodation,  counterpart  staff,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. ADB will oversee TA activities. The TA will be implemented over 15 months with 
estimated commencement in January 2018 and completion in March 2019.22 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

A. 
 
21. 
The  project  will  be  located  adjacent  to  the  existing  Talimarjan  TPP  within  the  power 
complex and will not require any additional land acquisition. The power complex was originally 
designed to accommodate 3,200 MW capacity with sufficient supporting infrastructure including 
fuel supply, cooling water systems, and power evacuation. It includes 800 MW gas-fired steam-
cycle units (commissioned by Uzbekenergo in 2004) and 900 MW CCGT units (financed by ADB 
in  2010).  The  power  from  the  project  will  be  evacuated  through  the  existing  500-kilovolt 
transmission lines. Natural gas is supplied by Uzbekneftegas, a state-owned gas company, from 
the  Shuritan  gas  field,  which  is  located  30  kilometers  away  from  the  power  complex. 
Uzbekneftegas confirmed that an additional 4.4 million cubic meters per day will be provided via 
the  existing  gas  pipeline  infrastructure  to  support  the  new  unit.  Cooling  water  requirement  is 

                                                
22  Attached Technical Assistance Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 Economic and Financial 

supplied from the Karshi main canal with water sourced primarily from the Amu Darya River with 
back-up supply from Talimarjan reservoir. 
 
22. 
The project will use commercially available and well-proven gas turbine technology and 
CCGT units with a thermal efficiency of 58% or higher and a capacity of 850–950 MW. The project 
configuration includes two gas turbines, two heat-recovery steam generators, one or two steam 
turbines, and supporting facilities. The combined heat and power feature provides an alternative 
supply to the existing heat boilers as required during the winter heating months. This provides a 
flexible, reliable, and highly efficient way of providing heat to the aging heat supply boilers. 
 
B. 
 
The  project  is  economically  viable  with  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  15.3%, 
23. 
exceeding  the  benchmark  9%  discount  rate.  The financial  analysis  of  the  project  provides  the 
financial internal rate of return of 6.3%, which compares favorably with the weighted average cost 
of capital of 1.7%. Financial viability is gauged by comparing the revenue and cost streams of 
scenarios  with  and  without  the  project.  The  result  of  a  sensitivity  analysis  confirms  that  the 
project’s  economic  and financial  viability  is  robust  even  under  unfavorable circumstances. The 
financial internal rate of return is based on assumptions of increases in end-user tariffs and fuel 
prices, which are estimated based on historical trends in tariff adjustments from 2010 to 2017. In 
case of insufficient tariff increase, the government has assured that it will provide debt servicing 
and operation coverage to Uzbekenergo. 
 
24. 
The sharp depreciation of local currency and its impacts on Uzbekenergo’s debt–equity 
ratio (para. 9) has resulted in a breach of financial covenants of the ongoing ADB loan for the 
Talimarjan Power Project (footnote 10). Uzbekenergo has developed a robust financial recovery 
action  plan  to  urgently  address  this  and  is  committed  to  complementary  reforms.  The  timely 
implementation of this action plan is crucial to keep the ongoing reforms on track and pave the 
way for the next generation of reforms. In the interim, it is imperative that Uzbekenergo is allowed 
a grace period and suitably adjusted financial covenants to maximize the results of the action plan. 
Accordingly, the project includes more realistic financial covenants as an interim measure and 
seeks  timely  implementation  of  the  action  plan  through  appropriately  formulated  covenants. 
Output  2  analytical  work  will  complement  the  action  plan  and  help  guide  ADB  and  other 
development partners’ further assistance in key areas to ensure timely implementation as well as 
a successful outcome from the action plan.  
 
C. 
 
25. 
Sector governance. The power sector is under the direct supervision of the cabinet of 
ministers and is managed by Uzbekenergo. The energy policy and the long-term investment plan 
are prepared by the cabinet in coordination with ministries and government agencies. The long-
term  investment  plan  (2011–2015)  was  updated  annually  and  a  new  plan  for  2015–2019  was 
announced in March 2015. The Ministry of Finance sets the tariff for utility costs. Licenses are 
issued  by  the  State  Inspection  on  Supervision  for  the  Power  Industry  under  the  cabinet. 
Institutional capacity development activities for Uzbekenergo, such as strengthening safeguard 
assessment,  bringing in modern  and  transparent  performance  assessment,  and upgrading the 
management information system, are under way with ADB support.  
 
26. 
Financial management. With insufficient capacity for transparent financial disclosures, 
Uzbekenergo’s financial management risk is high. Uzbekenergo was able to prepare its first IFRS-
based  consolidated  accounts  for  FY2015  only  in  2017  because  of  the  complexity  of  its 

Governance 

7 

 

 Poverty, Social, and Gender 

subsidiaries’  accounts  and  limited  accounting  skills.  Uzbekenergo’s  insufficient  capacity  to 
generate its IFRS-based financial statements on a timely basis has resulted in a substantial delay 
in carrying out the entity’s audit. These capacity issues have also resulted in non-compliance with 
submission of audited financial statements for the past 2 years under ongoing ADB loans.  The 
government  committed  to  improve  Uzbekenergo’s  management  capacity  including  corporate 
governance,  financial  and  management  reporting,  audit,  and  performance  management 
frameworks.  Attached TA  will  help  Uzbekenergo  enhance the  capacity  of  accounting  staff  and 
automate account consolidation and the management reporting process. Loan covenants have 
been included to recruit sufficient qualified financial management accounting staff.    
 
27. 
Procurement  capacity.  Although  Uzbekenergo  has  procurement  experience  in  similar 
projects, the inherent procurement risks are high because of the technical complexity and contract 
values. An international firm will be hired as project management and supervision consultant to 
assist  in  the  bidding  process  and  contract  management.  The  government’s  procurement 
procedure is undergoing reform to improve the efficiency and transparency of the procurement 
process.  Under  the  reform,  Uzbekenergo  will  establish  an  interagency  tender  committee 
comprising representatives from government agencies and design institutes.  
 
28. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  Uzbekenergo.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual. 
 
D. 
 
The  project’s  targeting  classification  is  general  intervention.  The  increased  reliability  of 
29. 
power supply and stable access to grid-connected electricity would indirectly benefit all segments 
of the population, including poor people. Adequate and reliable electricity supply will improve daily 
life and enable increased economic activity.  
  
30. 
The  project  is  assigned  some  gender  elements.  It  will  strengthen  gender-inclusive 
governance and management of the community social center (built as part of the gender action 
plan  under  the  Talimarjan  Power  Project)  through  an  operational  plan  that  aims  to  empower 
women. The direct employment of women will be encouraged to maintain the momentum. A social 
and gender specialist in the project management unit will provide support.   
 
E. 
 
31. 
categories are as follows.23 
 
Environment (category A). A draft environmental impact assessment (EIA) report was 
32. 
disclosed  in  June  2017  in  both  English  and  Russian  languages.  Public  consultation  was 
conducted  in  November  2016,  January  2017,  and  September  2017  for  the  two  nearest 
communities (Nuriston and Mekhnatabad) at the scoping stage and twice on the draft EIA report. 
All  issues  raised  during  the  consultation  were  adequately  addressed  in  the  final  EIA.  The  EIA 
includes  an  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  and  due  diligence  assessment  with  a 
corrective action plan for existing facilities. The EIA report identified potential impacts that would 
be generated from the project, and proposed an adequate EMP consisting of mitigation measures, 

In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  project’s  safeguard 

Safeguards

8 

 

 monitoring plan, cost, and arrangements for EMP implementation. The EMP will form part of the 
bidding documents.  
 
33. 
Some project impacts are expected during both construction and operation phases in the 
already  disturbed  environment  of  the  Talimarjan  power  complex.  The  main  concerns  include 
(i) cumulative impact from the new CCGT units on air quality and noise level at the project site 
and  in  the  residential  areas  of  Nuriston  and  Mekhnatabad;  (ii)  the  discharge  of  heated  water, 
wastewater from the sewer and chemical treatment plant, solid waste, and construction waste; 
and (iii) occupational safety. With the adopted emission control technology of CCGT units and 
gas fuel quality, air quality dispersion modelling has confirmed that nitrogen oxides emission will 
comply  with  the  Environmental,  Health,  and  Safety  Guidelines  of  the  International  Finance 
Corporation,  while  sulfur  dioxide  and  particulate  matter  2.5  will  be  negligible.  Noise  generated 
from  the  project  will  be within the World  Health Organization  standards. The  project  will  use  a 
hybrid combination of once-through cooling and recirculation cooling using cooling towers. The 
recirculation  cooling  mode  will  ensure  sufficient  flows  in  the  cooling  canal  and  limit  the 
temperature  increase  caused  by  the  discharged  water  within  3°C  (in  compliance  with  the 
Environmental,  Health,  and  Safety  Guidelines).  Social  and  fish  surveys  confirmed  insignificant 
risk to human health and economic activities as the water in the canal downstream is used only 
for  irrigation.  A  health  impact  assessment  was  conducted  to  establish  a  baseline  for  future 
monitoring and to ensure that the project has no adverse impact on the human health. 
 
34. 
The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  EMP  in 
compliance  with  ADB’s  safeguard  requirements  and  national  environmental  regulations.  A 
national environmental consultant will supplement and strengthen PMU safeguard staff capacity. 
Environmental  specialists  of  the  project  implementation  consultant  will  help  the  PMU  in 
overseeing  the  implementation  of  the  EMP  and  corrective  action  plan.  The  engineering, 
procurement, and construction contract will include costs for implementing mitigation measures; 
the  consulting  services  of  the  project  implementation  consultant  will  include  costs  for 
environmental instrumental monitoring and supervision; and the PMU budget will include costs 
for  environmental  consultant  support  and  capacity  building.  Independent  monitoring  will  be 
arranged with the local environmental authority and will be covered under the PMU budget. The 
project will use the grievance redress mechanism in place for Talimarjan Power Project to handle 
both  environmental  and  social  safeguard  issues  (footnote  10).  Uzbekenergo  will  use  its  own 
resources to implement the corrective action plan. 
  
35. 
Involuntary  resettlement  (category  C).  Social  due  diligence  suggests  that  no  land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts  are  to  be  expected,  because  construction  work  will  take 
place within the boundaries of existing Talimarjan power complex.

V. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

38. 
The government and Uzbekenergo have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in  the  project  administration  manual  and  loan  documents.  The  government  and  Uzbekenergo 
have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements. 
 
39.    As  a  condition  for  withdrawal  from  the  loan  account  for  any  project  expense  item,  a 
subsidiary  loan agreement for the relending  of the ADB  loan to Uzbekenergo shall  have been 
signed and become effective in accordance with the terms. In addition, no withdrawal will be made 
from the loan account for purposes of the turnkey contract until Uzbekenergo has furnished to 
ADB its audited annual consolidated financial statements for the financial years 2015 and 2016 
prepared in accordance with IFRS. 
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

40. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$450,000,000 to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan for the  Power  Generation  Efficiency  Improvement 
Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term 
of  25  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.
